H0.text: The kick decreases the weight of the ball, which causes the ball to move along the ground when a student places it on the ground and kicks it.

H1.text: The kick applies a contact force to the ball when a student places it on the ground and kicks it, causing the ball to move along the ground.

H2.text: The kick decreases the force of gravity acting on the ball that a student places on the ground and then kicks, causing the ball to move along the ground.

H3.text: The kick removes friction between the ball and the ground, causing the ball to move along the ground after a student places it on the ground and kicks it.

A4.text: Pushing a car or kicking a ball are everyday examples where contact forces are at work.

A5.text: Gravitational forces, electrical forces and magnetic forces are body forces and can exist without contact occurring.
